{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3640857,"name":"James Goebel","username":"RummelRobotics","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/bc8723/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T13:46:26.510Z","cooked":"

Our VH-109 works fine in our main lab. We bring the another room across the
hall or in a different building it won’t connect. The old style radio never had
this problem in the other two rooms. Is it possible we are getting some
kind of interference from another wifi appliance or rf from from lighting.
The vh-109 worked flawlessly at Bayou Regional. I brought my wifi analyzer
ap in and it shows that the vh-109 is running at the 6 ghz frequency.

How are you trying to connect the VH-109 when at your lab/other locations that it does not work? 2.4GHz directly to a laptop, or 6GHz using a VH-113 as an access point?

It is important to remember that the VH-109 cannot act as an AP at 6GHz, only 2.4GHz. If you are trying to get a 6GHz connection to practice with at home you will need to use a network setup similar to what is found in the Vivid documentation with a VH-113 acting as an AP

I am using a VH-109 as an access point. It works fine in the lab in this configuration.

Why would it work fine in one room but not in two others?

RummelRobotics:

I am using a VH-109 as an access point

How was it configured? Are you using 6GHz or 2.4GHz?

How is it powered?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-05-30T15:03:11.208Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502586,"topic_slug":"vh-109-works-fine-in-our-main-lab-and-regional-but-will-not-work-in-other-rooms","display_username":"alst","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25570,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FiM CSA/etc."},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-works-fine-in-our-main-lab-and-regional-but-will-not-work-in-other-rooms/502586/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3640928,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-30T15:07:36.929Z","cooked":"

If you are using the VH-109 on the robot as the AP, then it is working on the 2.4 G band. There are FCC rules against 6G APs powered by a battery. The VH-109 allegedly has circuitry to prevent this. The 2.4 G band doesn’t work for robot control because a lot of devices use it and it can b very congested in public spaces. It might work well in one place, but not so much in others. The 2.4G radio on the VH-109 was sort of a freeby. It came on the chip. Since using 6G was the goal, not a lot attention was paid to make the 2.4G to work well. This is well documented on other CD threads.
